article.description:
Julius Page stepped on an opponent's foot and injured his right ankle. Chevon Troutman flew out of bounds and
rammed into a chair, banging up his elbow.
article.headline: Pittsburgh cruises to victory
article.linkText: Page injures ankle as Pitt wins in rout
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Julius Page stepped on an opponent's foot and injured his right ankle. Chevon Troutman flew out of bounds and rammed into a chair, banging up his elbow. For a team that couldn't be playing a softer schedule, Pittsburgh (No. 3 ESPN/USA Today, No. 4 AP) is taking its share of hard hits. Page gave Pitt a big early lead with a series of dunks and fast-break layups Saturday night before sitting out the final 10 minutes with a sore right ankle as the Panthers beat Southeastern Louisiana 89-55. Page scored 17 points to help make up for the missing production of forward Donatas Zavackas, who was delayed in Europe while attending a funeral. Zavackas led Pitt with 20 points in its previous game, an 82-60 victory over Penn State. Page was limping after the game, but coach Ben Howland is hopeful he can play Wednesday against Ohio State. "We need him to be healthy,'' Howland said. "That's my biggest worry right now, because we need him matched up against their best player (Brent Darby).'' Darby scored 30 points Saturday as Ohio State beat Morehead State 74-60. Pittsburgh (6-0) had too much size, athleticism and quickness for Southeastern Louisiana (1-5), which has yet to defeat a Division I opponent. The Lions scored only eight points in the first 13½ minutes of the second half. "I thought our defense then was outstanding,'' Howland said. "They couldn't score.'' Troutman, who started for Zavackas, scored 14 despite going 0-for-7 at the foul line, with Brandin Knight and Carl Krauser adding 13 and Jaron Brown 10. Ontario Lett, who splits time at center with Toree Morris, had 10 points and 10 rebounds as Pitt shot 64.2 percent (34-of-53) overall but only 16-of-33 (48.5 percent) from the foul line. Troutman said his arm was partly numb after ramming into the chair during the first half, affecting his shooting after that. Despite his troubles at the foul line, he was 7-of-8 while getting most of shots around the basket. Amir Abdur-Rahim scored 18 for the Lions, who quickly fell behind 8-0 before scoring with 16:20 left and never got much closer as the crowd of 8,678 spent the night cheering dunks by Page, Lett and Troutman. Another big cheer came in the final minute when a ball flew out of bounds and was caught by former Steelers star Franco Harris, who was walking by while leaving the building. Pitt is 6-0 for the first time since 1997-98, but the Panthers' schedule couldn't have been much easier, with opponents such as Norfolk State, Arkansas-Pine Bluff and St. Francis, Pa. They have won their last four by a combined 164 points and their closest game was a 15-point victory over city rival Duquesne. The Panthers clearly seem to be eager for better competition and should get it in Ohio State (3-2), whose two losses were to nationally ranked Alabama and Duke. Pitt moved into the Associated Press Top 25 last season shortly after upsetting Ohio State 62-55 in Columbus. "We're going to be excited to be going against a good team,'' Troutman said. "We've been getting a little bit better with every game, so we'll be ready when we start playing tougher teams. When we start playing them, we'll raise our level.'' Pitt's Associated Press ranking is its highest since being No. 2 early in the 1987-88 season. The Panthers won their 22nd consecutive nonconference game at home and are 5-0 in their new arena.
